 First, Genesis 2:4 literally reads, "in the day (yom) of the Lord God making (made) the earth and heavens."
 
 Right away, Moses, the author of Genesis (save that debate for another thread), who also wrote of the 'days' of creation, describes those 'days' as one day, or one time period.  Second, the Hebrew word translated "evening" is ereb. It can also mean "sunset," "night," or "ending of the day." The Hebrew word translated morning is boger. It can mean "sunrise" or "beginning of day," and has been used in theology in a metaphoric sense. The evening and morning of the creation days then refer not simply to the rising and setting of the sun, but to the beginning and ending boundaries of a day. Again, in context with the remainder of the creation days, Moses' day of Genesis 2:4 is longer than a 24 hour period.
